ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to critically analyze monuments. I learned more about the industry of conservation of sculptures and the impact in our communities.
I learned about memory theory, reading sculpture, and the preservation of cultural heritage. I was introduced to agisoft and arcgis.
How to think critically about public art, and the importance of restoration. I additionally learned how to use StoryMaps and how to do photogrammetry.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I loved the class. The field trips made the class more hands on and created a positive atmosphere for conversations.
Earlier start on the final project, more focus on art history, emphasis on memory. There were a lot of good things in this course but it felt a bit disjointed.
I enjoyed the readings, but I wish there were less required readings. I also enjoyed the field trips. It would have been great to have an incorporated hands-on lab.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It gives you a chance to learn about how monuments shape our communities and the investment that goes into preservation of pubic art.
Good fifth class, gets you thinking about an discipline you so often pass by.
Yes, my view on public art has been shaped with this course.
